content.title: Metabolic Alkalosis
content.summary: Metabolic alkalosis is characterized by elevated arterial pH (>7.45) with primary increase in serum bicarbonate (>28 mEq/L). It is classified as chloride-responsive (urine Cl <20 mEq/L) or chloride-resistant (urine Cl >20 mEq/L), which guides treatment. Generation requires bicarbonate gain while maintenance requires impaired renal excretion.
key_points: Primary HCO3 elevation with compensatory hypoventilation (increased PaCO2)
Chloride-responsive (UCl <20): vomiting, NG suction, diuretics - responds to saline
Chloride-resistant (UCl >20): hyperaldosteronism, Bartter, Gitelman - needs specific treatment
Hypokalemia perpetuates alkalosis via increased renal H+ secretion
Expected compensation: PaCO2 rises 0.7 mmHg per 1 mEq/L HCO3 rise
Treatment: address underlying cause, replace chloride and potassium
content.statement: Metabolic alkalosis is a primary acid-base disorder with elevated blood pH from increased bicarbonate, requiring both a generating mechanism (acid loss or alkali gain) and maintenance factors (volume depletion, hypokalemia, mineralocorticoid excess) that impair renal bicarbonate excretion.

explanation.intuition: Think of metabolic alkalosis as having two parts: something creates the excess bicarbonate (generation), and something else prevents the kidney from excreting it (maintenance). A healthy kidney can excrete massive bicarbonate loads - so if alkalosis persists, there's a reason it can't escape.
explanation.key_insight: The urine chloride is the key to diagnosis: if the kidney is chloride-avid (UCl <20), it's volume depleted and will respond to saline. If chloride is being wasted (UCl >20), there's autonomous aldosterone or a channelopathy that won't respond to saline.
explanation.technical_details: Bicarbonate reabsorption in the proximal tubule requires volume and chloride. When chloride is depleted, the kidney reabsorbs sodium with bicarbonate instead, maintaining alkalosis. Hypokalemia shifts potassium out of cells in exchange for hydrogen, promoting intracellular acidosis and paradoxical renal acid excretion.

definitions_glossary.metabolic_alkalosis: Primary acid-base disorder with arterial pH >7.45 due to HCO3 elevation
definitions_glossary.chloride_responsive: Alkalosis corrected by NaCl administration; UCl <20 mEq/L
definitions_glossary.chloride_resistant: Alkalosis not corrected by NaCl; UCl >20 mEq/L
definitions_glossary.contraction_alkalosis: Alkalosis from ECF volume loss concentrating existing bicarbonate
definitions_glossary.generation_phase: Initial event causing bicarbonate gain or acid loss
definitions_glossary.maintenance_phase: Ongoing factors preventing renal bicarbonate excretion
definitions_glossary.paradoxical_aciduria: Acid urine despite systemic alkalosis due to severe hypokalemia
definitions_glossary.posthypercapnic_alkalosis: Alkalosis after correcting chronic respiratory acidosis
definitions_glossary.Bartter_syndrome: Inherited defect mimicking loop diuretics; causes chloride-resistant alkalosis
definitions_glossary.Gitelman_syndrome: Inherited defect mimicking thiazides; causes chloride-resistant alkalosis
definitions_glossary.primary_aldosteronism: Autonomous aldosterone excess causing hypokalemia and alkalosis
definitions_glossary.milk_alkali_syndrome: Alkalosis from excessive calcium carbonate ingestion
definitions_glossary.urine_chloride: Key diagnostic marker distinguishing chloride-responsive from resistant

pathophysiology.mechanism: Requires generating event plus maintenance factors that impair renal HCO3 excretion

ECF_contraction: Concentrates existing bicarbonate without adding new base

maintenance_factors: Effective circulating volume depletion (impairs HCO3 delivery to distal nephron)
Chloride depletion (kidney reabsorbs Na with HCO3 instead of Cl)
Hypokalemia (increases distal H+ secretion, maintains alkalosis)
Mineralocorticoid excess (increases H+ and K+ secretion)

ABG_interpretation.compensation: PaCO2 rises 0.7 mmHg per 1 mEq/L HCO3 increase
ABG_interpretation.limits: PaCO2 rarely exceeds 55 mmHg in pure metabolic alkalosis

chloride_responsive.mechanism: Volume/chloride depleted; kidney avidly retains chloride

differential_diagnosis: Respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation (check if PaCO2 appropriately elevated)
Mixed metabolic alkalosis + respiratory alkalosis (PaCO2 lower than expected)

chloride_responsive.first_line: Normal saline (0.9% NaCl) to replete volume and chloride
chloride_responsive.potassium: KCl to correct hypokalemia (corrects faster than bicarbonate)
chloride_responsive.acetazolamide: 250-500mg IV q6h if volume overload prevents saline (induces bicarbonaturia)

chloride_resistant.primary_aldosteronism: Spironolactone or eplerenone; adrenalectomy if adenoma
chloride_resistant.Bartter_Gitelman: Potassium and magnesium supplementation; amiloride or spironolactone

definition.@value: A primary acid-base disorder characterized by elevated arterial pH due to increased serum bicarbonate, classified by urine chloride as responsive or resistant to saline administration

scopeNote.@value: Covers pathophysiology, classification, diagnosis via urine chloride, and treatment of metabolic alkalosis

learning_objectives: Identify metabolic alkalosis from ABG interpretation
Calculate expected respiratory compensation for metabolic alkalosis
Use urine chloride to classify as chloride-responsive or resistant
Select appropriate treatment based on chloride classification
Recognize the role of hypokalemia in maintaining alkalosis
clinical_pearls: UCl <20 = saline will work; UCl >20 = saline won't work
Always check urine chloride BEFORE giving saline (it will change with treatment)
Hypokalemia perpetuates alkalosis - must correct both
Alkalosis shifts potassium INTO cells - serum K underestimates total body deficit
Bartter = loop diuretic mimic; Gitelman = thiazide mimic
common_misconceptions: Diuretics always cause hypokalemia and alkalosis - not if combined with K-sparing agents
High bicarbonate means metabolic alkalosis - could be compensation for chronic respiratory acidosis
Treatment is just stopping the cause - maintenance factors must also be addressed

sources.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed.
